#create correlation
corr = df.corr(method = 'pearson')

#convert correlation to numpy array
mask = np.array(corr)

#to mask the repetitive value for each pair
mask[np.tril_indices_from(mask)] = False
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (15,12))
fig.set_size_inches(15,15)
sns.heatmap(corr, mask = mask, vmax = 0.9, square = True, annot = True)

source.7f4d9742:
df_log = np.log(df[['sepal_length', 'sepal_width','petal_length','petal_width']])

fig, (ax1, ax2, ax3, ax4) = plt.subplots(4,1, figsize=(8,8))
sns.distplot(df_log["sepal_length"], ax=ax1)
sns.distplot(df_log["sepal_width"], ax=ax2)
sns.distplot(df_log["petal_length"], ax=ax3)
sns.distplot(df_log["petal_width"], ax=ax4)
plt.tight_layout()
source.0e40becd:
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

scaler = StandardScaler()
cluster_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(df_log)
source.76444e5f:
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans

Sum_of_squared_distances = []

K = range(1,15)

for k in K:
    km = KMeans(n_clusters=k)
    km = km.fit(cluster_scaled)
    Sum_of_squared_distances.append(km.inertia_)
    
plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))
plt.plot(K, Sum_of_squared_distances, 'bx-')
plt.xlabel('k')
plt.ylabel('Sum_of_squared_distances')
plt.title('Elbow Method For Optimal k')
plt.show()
source.5676942c:
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D

model = KMeans(n_clusters=3)
model.fit(cluster_scaled)
kmeans_labels = model.labels_

fig = plt.figure(num=None, figsize=(15, 10), dpi=80, facecolor='w', edgecolor='k')
ax = plt.axes(projection="3d")

ax.scatter3D(df['sepal_length'],df['sepal_width'], df['petal_width'], c=kmeans_labels, cmap='rainbow')

xLabel = ax.set_xlabel('sepal_leangth', linespacing=3.2)
yLabel = ax.set_ylabel('sepal_width', linespacing=3.1)
zLabel = ax.set_zlabel('petal_width', linespacing=3.4)
print("K-Means")

grouped_kmeans = df_clustered_kmeans.groupby(['Cluster']).mean().round(1)
